Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports continuation of the Enhancing Diversity in Graduate Education (EDGE) program. The proportion of women, especially underrepresented minority women, in the mathematical sciences declines at each successive academic level. In response to this problem, the EDGE Program is designed (1) to increase the number of women PhDs in the mathematical sciences, especially those from underrepresented groups; and (2) to place more women in visible leadership roles in the mathematics community. The EDGE Program seeks to achieve these goals by providing a comprehensive mentoring program that supports the academic development and research activities of women in mathematics. The proposed activities target women in four different groups: new PhD students, advanced PhD students, postdocs, and junior faculty. Along with an annual summer session, EDGE supports an annual conference, travel for research collaborations, travel to present research, and other open-ended mentoring activities for each targeted participant group.

This project aims to impact the mathematics community by increasing the number of women, particularly from minority groups, who succeed in graduate programs in the mathematical sciences; who assume leadership roles in academia, industry, and government; and who ultimately diversify the mathematical community and provide a sustainable increase in the pool of available "home-grown" talent. Increased diversity in the mathematics community will ultimately strengthen U.S. competitiveness in mathematics and science and allow people from all backgrounds and cultures to thrive, advance, and contribute to the profession. Reducing the gender and racial disparities among faculty in the mathematical sciences will facilitate national efforts to increase the diversity of students enrolled in undergraduate and graduate programs in mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The EDGE Program offers comprehensive mentoring and support to women, approximately half of whom are underrepresented minorities, pursuing careers in the mathematical sciences. EDGE activities are designed to provide ongoing support toward academic development and research productivity at several critical career stages.EDGE has garnered wide respect from many in the mathematics community and has been recognized by the American Mathematical Society as an outstanding program that successfully addresses the issue of underrepresented groups in mathematics. Between 2014-2017, in addition to our signature summer session for entering graduate students, EDGE supported an annual conference, mini-sabbaticals for research collaborations, regional research symposia, regional mentoring clusters, travel support for research talks, and other open-ended mentoring activities. 

Since it’s inception in 1998, two hundred and fifty-five women have participated in the EDGE summer session. Ninety-one have received their PhDs and there are still over 75 EDGE participants currently persisting in graduate programs. At least fourteen EDGE participants received NSF graduate research fellowships.

In 2017 alone, nine EDGE participants received their PhDs. In 2015, forty-five percent of all African-American women receiving PhDs in the mathematical sciences were EDGE participants. In 20 years of EDGE, twenty-one percent of all African-American women earning a PhD in a mathematical science were EDGE participants. In 2006, when the University of Mississippi became the first American college or university to graduate four African-American students with PhDs in mathematics at one commencement, one of the four graduates was Carla Cotwright (EDGE 2001). Dr. Cotwright was later selected by the American Mathematical Society (AMS) as its 2012-13 AMS/AAAS Congressional Fellow. In 2017, April Harry (EDGE 2010) was the first African American woman to earn a PhD in Statistics at Purdue University.

As participants complete their PhD, they are providing leadership throughout the mathematics community and beyond. For example, Rachelle DeCoste (EDGE ’98) organizes a career workshop; Farrah Jackson (EDGE ’1999) directed the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program at Elizabeth City State University and was recently appointed Associate Vice Chancellor for Academic Affairs; in 2014 the governor of New Hampshire appointed Susan D’Agostino (EDGE 1998) to the New Hampshire Governor’s STEM Education Task Force. All four members of the team of creators of the website mathematicallygiftedandblack.com launched in 2017 to celebrate the diversity of African-American mathematicians are EDGE participants.

EDGE participants have found ways to reach broad audiences. Talithia Williams’ (EDGE 2000) TED talk titled “Own your body’s data” has almost 1.5 million views and she recently debuted as a host of a new PBS science series “Nova Wonders” which is 6-part television series exploring the biggest questions on the frontiers of science. Tai-Danae Bradley (EDGE 2014) has a very popular math blog, math3ma.com, and recently expanded her audience by hosting videos at PBS Infinite Series, a YouTube channel dedicated to the world of mathematics. In 2015, Chandra Erdman (EDGE 2002) was featured in the American Statistical Association’s “This is Statistics” video series raising awareness on the diverse opportunities in the field of statistics.

EDGE participants who have completed their PhDs have also served in many leadership roles in our professional mathematics societies —organizing workshops for the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics and the Mathematical Association of America, serving on the executive committee of the Association for Women in Mathematics, and serving as a guest editor for a special edition of the AMS Notices.

In 2013, in response to an overwhelming push from EDGE participants we established a nonprofit organization, the Sylvia Bozeman and Rhonda Hughes EDGE Foundation to raise money to support EDGE activities and better ensure the longevity of the program.

(NB: This is the same report submitted by the collaborating PI, Ulrica Wilson (Morehouse College) with minor edits to update figures to include summer 2018).
